text: signatures are deeply personal for
centuries we've used them to make our
mark on the world even the humble X can
be legally binding while the flourishes
and swirls of famous names have become
linked with moments in history here we
are in power of the pen Jennifer Johnson
is the curator of an exhibition about
signatures at the National Archives the
signatures on the document carry the
force of law and can impact many people
on display a shoe patent signed by the
pop star Michael Jackson a card from the
former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein and
the marriage certificate of Adolphe
Hitler and Eva Braun gives you
goosebumps and that one is especially
unique in that it's what I call a it's
it's multiple signatures on one page not
only do you have Adolphe Hitler and Eva
Braun but Joseph Goebbels and Martin
Bormann signed as witnesses but
technology is replacing pen and paper in
2000 President Bill Clinton used a smart
card encrypted with his digital
signature to e-sign a new law that made
online contracts legal just imagine if
this had existed 224 years ago the
founding fathers wouldn't have had to
come all the way to Philadelphia on July
4th for the Declaration of Independence
they could have emailed their John
Hancock's in the US National Archives
now collects millions of pieces of
digital data every year if we were to
look at the same exhibit 100 years from
now it would have a combination of some
of the quaint artifacts of today the
paper with the signatures and a really
interesting and creative I think
snapshot of the various ways people have
been communicating in making their mark
in the electronic environment but what
technology could replace a signed sports
shirt and what do we learn about a
person whose signature includes excuse
the typos sent from my cell phone
experts say electronic signatures can
still create a unique impression what do
you use as your closing
for your email your signature line and
then we have of course the options of
fonts now getting too out of control
would be you know using the colors and
the exciting pastel backgrounds and
things that dance around but I think
that just showing what signature line
you used and how you close out your
email says so so much about you what
historians will make of our electronic
communications is anybody's guess but
one thing is already certain the pen may
be mightier than the sword but it's no
match for email Jayne O'Brien BBC News
Washington
